2. Perimeters

Calculate perimeter in context

The diagram below shows a top view of Ms Govender's house and land.

The property has a fence going around the outside. What is the perimeter of the property?

INSTRUCTION: Use the scale of the diagram to choose the most appropriate units to measure the perimeter.
Answer: Perimeter =
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. To find the perimeter of the property, add up all the boundary line lengths as if you are walking all the way around the property boundary.

STEP: Add up all the boundary lines that form the perimeter of this property
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape.

To find the perimeter of the property, add up the lengths of all of the boundary lines as if you are walking all the way around the property.

If we start at the point shown on the diagram and walk all around the boundary, we get

P=11+22+19+4=56
STEP: Choose the correct unit of measure
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Perimeter is a distance, and is measured using units of length (such as mm, cm, m, or km).

Millimetres (mm) and centimetres (cm) are appropriate for measuring short lengths. They are on your ruler.

Metres (m) are bigger - about the length of one big step or three rulers placed end to end. There are 100 centimetres in one metre.

Kilometres (km) are good for measuring longer distances. It takes about 20 minutes to walk one kilometre (if you are walking at a relaxed speed). There are 1 000 metres in one kilometre.

If the perimeter of the property was:

✘ 56 mm or 56 cm: It would be a tiny house for ants!
✘ 56 km: It would take Ms Govender about 18,5 hours just to walk around the edge of her garden! Nobody has a house that big. We can also use the width of the road to help us to judge the correct scale.
✔ 56 m: Of the options, only metres make sense here. Go and measure the perimeter of your house, by taking big steps next to the fence!

The perimeter of the property is 56 m.

Submit your answer as: and

Working backwards from perimeter: squares and rectangles

The perimeter of the rectangle drawn below is 33 cm.

Determine the value of y and select the correct unit.

INSTRUCTION: Give your answer as an exact decimal.
Answer:

y=

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. Use the given information to create an equation.

STEP: Use the given information to create an equation
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape.

To find the perimeter of a polygon, we add up the lengths of all of the sides as if we are walking all the way around the edge of the shape.

The opposite sides of a rectangle are the same length.

We know that the perimeter of the rectangle is 33 cm so:

33=11+y+11+y33=2y+2233−22=2y+22−2211=2y112=2y25,5=yy=5,5 cm
NOTE: We must use units of length for the length of the side (such as mm, cm, m, or km). Square units like cm2 are for measuring area.
Submit your answer as: and

Circumference of a circle

A circle has a radius of 10 mm.

What is the circumference of the circle?

INSTRUCTION: Use π=3,14 in your calculation.
Answer: The circumference is mm.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.004))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The formula for the circumference of a circle is

C=2πr

Which variable is the radius in this formula?

STEP: Calculate the circumference of the circle
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to calculate the circumference of the circle. The circumference of a circle is its perimeter: this is the distance around the edge of a shape.

Let's start with the formula for the circumference of a circle:

C=2πr

In this formula, the variable r stands for the radius of the circle. The question gives us the value of r. We need to substitute this into the formula to find the circumference of the circle.

C=2πr=2(3,14)(10)=62,8 mm

So the circumference is 62,8 mm.

Submit your answer as:

Definition: π

Study circles A and B shown below:

Is the following statement about the circles True or False?

The value of π is the same for both circles.
Answer: The statement is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

The definition of π is the ratio of the circumference and the diameter of a circle. If the circumference of the circle changes, will the diameter of the circle change in the same way, or will this ratio be different?

STEP: Recall the definition of π
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Pi, which is represented by the symbol π, is the ratio of the circumference C of any circle to its diameter d. We write this as

π=Cd

The value of π is the same for all circles, large or small, and is approximately equal to 3,14. As the circumference of a circle increases or decreases, so does its diameter. This makes the value of π a constant.

We can see this by doing a quick experiment. Draw a circle with a compass, and use a piece of string and a ruler to measure the circumference of the circle. Next, use the ruler to measure the diameter of the circle. If we divide the circumference by the diameter, we will get a value that is approximately 3,14. If we do the same thing but with a larger or a smaller circle, we will get the same value, every time!

The value of π is the same for both circles, so the statement in the question is True.

Submit your answer as:

The value of π

Is the following statement about the value of π True or False?

π is an unending number approximately equal to 227.
Answer: The statement is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Look at the value of π that your calculator gives you, and compare this to the value of 227. Are they the same number?

STEP: π is an unending number
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Pi, which is represented by the symbol π, is the ratio of the circumference C of any circle to its diameter d. We write this as

π=Cd

The value of π is the same for all circles, large or small. As the circumference of a circle increases or decreases, so does its diameter. This makes the value of π a constant. Its value is 3,141592653897... The digits continue forever without repeating.

Here are the first 200 digits of π:

3,14159265358979323846264338327950288419716939937510582097494459230781640628620899862803482534211706798214808651328230664709384460955058223172535940812848111745028410270193852110555964462294895493038196...

Scientists using powerful computers have calculated the value of π to over 13 trillion decimal places. But they will never be able to reach the end of this number, since the end does not exist!

When we do calculations with π, there is no way we can use the exact value of π. There is no way we could enter an unending number of digits into a calculator!

Instead, we often use an approximation to the value of π. One commonly used value is 3,14, which is π rounded to two decimal places. Another approximation is 227. If we divide 7 into 22 with a calculator, we get 3,142857143. It is only the same as π to two decimal places, but it is still a good approximation.

π is an unending number approximately equal to 227, so the statement in the question is True.

Submit your answer as:

Perimeter of regular shapes

Calculate the perimeter of the regular polygon below. The length of one side from A to B = 6,9 metres.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to one decimal place.
Answer:

P = metres

numeric
STEP: Calculate the perimeter of the shape
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The perimeter of any polygon is the sum of the lengths of all the sides. Regular means a polygon that is equiangular (all angles are equal in measure) and equilateral (all sides have the same length).
This polygon is called a ocatagon, with 8 equal sides.

We know one side = 6,9 metres∴n=the number of sides
Perimeter=n×6,9 metres=8×6,9 metresPerimeter =55,2 metres

Circles: circumference and units

A circle has a radius of 18 m. What is its circumference in km?

INSTRUCTION: Use π=3,14 in your calculation, and round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: The circumference is km.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Start by finding the circumference of the circle in m. Then convert the circumference to km.

STEP: Find the circumference of the circle in m
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

In this question, we need to find the circumference of the circle in km, but we have the radius in m. One way to solve this is to calculate the circumference in m, and then convert this value to km.

The formula for the circumference of a circle is

C=2πr

Since we know that the radius is 18 m, we can calculate the circumference:

C=2πr=2(3,14)(18)=113,04 m
STEP: Convert the circumference from m to km
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now we need to convert the circumference from m to km. We know that 1 km=1 000 m, so we need to divide the radius in m by 1 000. We need to divide, because 1 m is smaller than 1 km, so we need fewer km than we have m.

C=113,04 m=113,041 000 km=0,11304 km≈0,11 km
NOTE: You can also solve this question by first converting the radius to km, and then calculating the circumference.

The correct answer for the new circumference of the circle is

C=0,11 km.
Submit your answer as:

Exercises

Calculate perimeter in context

A photograph of Farmer Mario's farm is shown below. The photograph was taken from an aeroplane. The red lines show the boundary of the farm.

What is the perimeter of the farm?

INSTRUCTION: Use the scale of the diagram to choose the most appropriate units to measure the perimeter.
Answer: Perimeter =
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. To find the perimeter of the farm, add up all the boundary line lengths as if you are walking all the way around the farm boundary.

STEP: Add up all the boundary lines that form the perimeter of this farm
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape.

To find the perimeter of the farm, add up the lengths of all of the boundary lines as if you are walking all the way around the farm.

If we start at the point shown on the diagram and walk all around the boundary, we get

P=1,1+1,1+1+1,1=4,3
STEP: Choose the correct unit of measure
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Perimeter is a distance, and is measured using units of length (such as mm, cm, m, or km).

Millimetres (mm) and centimetres (cm) are appropriate for measuring short lengths. They are on your ruler.

Metres (m) are bigger - about the length of one big step or three rulers placed end to end. There are 100 centimetres in one metre.

Kilometres (km) are good for measuring longer distances. It takes about 20 minutes to walk one kilometre (if you are walking at a relaxed speed). There are 1 000 metres in one kilometre.

If the perimeter of the farm was:

✘ 4,3 mm or 4,3 cm: It would be a tiny farm for ants!
✘ 4,3 m: This is about the perimeter of a table. It is much too small for a farm.
✔ 4,3 km: Of the options, only kilometres make sense here. It would take Farmer Mario about 85 minutes to walk around a farm with this perimeter.

The perimeter of the farm is 4,3 km.

✘ 60 mm or 60 cm: It would be a tiny house for ants!
✘ 60 km: It would take Ms Pieters about 20 hours just to walk around the edge of her garden! Nobody has a house that big. We can also use the width of the road to help us to judge the correct scale.
✔ 60 m: Of the options, only metres make sense here. Go and measure the perimeter of your house, by taking big steps next to the fence!

The perimeter of the property is 60 m.

Calculate perimeter in context

A photograph of Farmer Mbali's farm is shown below. The photograph was taken from an aeroplane. The red lines show the boundary of the farm.

What is the perimeter of the farm?

Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. To find the perimeter of the farm, add up all the boundary line lengths as if you are walking all the way around the farm boundary.

STEP: Add up all the boundary lines that form the perimeter of this farm
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape.

To find the perimeter of the farm, add up the lengths of all of the boundary lines as if you are walking all the way around the farm.

If we start at the point shown on the diagram and walk all around the boundary, we get

P=1+1+0,9+1=3,9
STEP: Choose the correct unit of measure
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Perimeter is a distance, and is measured using units of length (such as mm, cm, m, or km).

Millimetres (mm) and centimetres (cm) are appropriate for measuring short lengths. They are on your ruler.

Metres (m) are bigger - about the length of one big step or three rulers placed end to end. There are 100 centimetres in one metre.

Kilometres (km) are good for measuring longer distances. It takes about 20 minutes to walk one kilometre (if you are walking at a relaxed speed). There are 1 000 metres in one kilometre.

If the perimeter of the farm was:

✘ 3,9 mm or 3,9 cm: It would be a tiny farm for ants!
✘ 3,9 m: This is about the perimeter of a table. It is much too small for a farm.
✔ 3,9 km: Of the options, only kilometres make sense here. It would take Farmer Mbali about 75 minutes to walk around a farm with this perimeter.

The perimeter of the farm is 3,9 km.

[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape.

To find the perimeter of a polygon, we add up the lengths of all of the sides as if we are walking all the way around the edge of the shape.

The opposite sides of a rectangle are the same length.

Circumference of a circle

What is the circumference of the circle?

[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to calculate the circumference of the circle. The circumference of a circle is its perimeter: this is the distance around the edge of a shape.

Let's start with the formula for the circumference of a circle:

C=2πr

In this formula, the variable r stands for the radius of the circle. The question gives us the value of r. We need to substitute this into the formula to find the circumference of the circle.

C=2πr=2(3,14)(6)=37,68 mm

So the circumference is 37,68 mm.

Definition: π

Study circles A and B shown below:

Is the following statement about the circles True or False?

The value of π is the same for both circles.
Answer: The statement is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

The definition of π is the ratio of the circumference and the diameter of a circle. If the circumference of the circle changes, will the diameter of the circle change in the same way, or will this ratio be different?

STEP: Recall the definition of π
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Pi, which is represented by the symbol π, is the ratio of the circumference C of any circle to its diameter d. We write this as

π=Cd

The value of π is the same for all circles, large or small, and is approximately equal to 3,14. As the circumference of a circle increases or decreases, so does its diameter. This makes the value of π a constant.

We can see this by doing a quick experiment. Draw a circle with a compass, and use a piece of string and a ruler to measure the circumference of the circle. Next, use the ruler to measure the diameter of the circle. If we divide the circumference by the diameter, we will get a value that is approximately 3,14. If we do the same thing but with a larger or a smaller circle, we will get the same value, every time!

The value of π is the same for both circles, so the statement in the question is True.

The value of π

Is the following statement about the value of π True or False?

π is an unending number approximately equal to 227.
Answer: The statement is .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Look at the value of π that your calculator gives you, and compare this to the value of 227. Are they the same number?

STEP: π is an unending number
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

Pi, which is represented by the symbol π, is the ratio of the circumference C of any circle to its diameter d. We write this as

π=Cd

The value of π is the same for all circles, large or small. As the circumference of a circle increases or decreases, so does its diameter. This makes the value of π a constant. Its value is 3,141592653897... The digits continue forever without repeating.

Here are the first 200 digits of π:

3,14159265358979323846264338327950288419716939937510582097494459230781640628620899862803482534211706798214808651328230664709384460955058223172535940812848111745028410270193852110555964462294895493038196...

Scientists using powerful computers have calculated the value of π to over 13 trillion decimal places. But they will never be able to reach the end of this number, since the end does not exist!

When we do calculations with π, there is no way we can use the exact value of π. There is no way we could enter an unending number of digits into a calculator!

Instead, we often use an approximation to the value of π. One commonly used value is 3,14, which is π rounded to two decimal places. Another approximation is 227. If we divide 7 into 22 with a calculator, we get 3,142857143. It is only the same as π to two decimal places, but it is still a good approximation.

π is an unending number approximately equal to 227, so the statement in the question is True.

Submit your answer as:

Circles: circumference and units

A circle has a radius of 10 m. What is its circumference in cm?

INSTRUCTION: Use π=3,14 in your calculation, and round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: The circumference is cm.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Start by finding the circumference of the circle in m. Then convert the circumference to cm.

STEP: Find the circumference of the circle in m
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

In this question, we need to find the circumference of the circle in cm, but we have the radius in m. One way to solve this is to calculate the circumference in m, and then convert this value to cm.

The formula for the circumference of a circle is

C=2πr

Since we know that the radius is 10 m, we can calculate the circumference:

C=2πr=2(3,14)(10)=62,8 m
STEP: Convert the circumference from m to cm
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now we need to convert the circumference from m to cm. We know that 1 m=100 cm, so we need to multiply the radius in m by 100. We need to multiply, because 1 m is larger than 1 cm, so we need more cm than we have m.

C=62,8 m=62.8⋅100 cm=6 280 cm
NOTE: You can also solve this question by first converting the radius to cm, and then calculating the circumference.

The correct answer for the new circumference of the circle is

C=6 280 cm.

3. Areas

Perimeter and area

Study the figure below and calculate the perimeter and the area of this figure by using the given lengths in cm.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = cm
  2. Area = cm2
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

For the perimeter, you need to find the sum (the total) of the distance around the edges of the shape. For the area, you will need to use what you know about the area of rectangles.

STEP: Find the perimeter
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The perimeter of an object is the distance around the outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. For example, the perimeter of a soccer field is the white line around the entire field. The diagram below shows the perimeter coloured red and blue.

To find the perimeter, we need to add up all six sides of the shape. We can start at any corner we want and go around until we get back where we started. We will start at the corner labelled below.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around=4+7+2+4+2+3Perimeter=22cm
NOTE: You do not have to start at the same corner: you can start at any corner and you will get the same total distance. This is because the distance around the shape is the same no matter where you start.
STEP: Break the shape into two rectangles to find the area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The area of a shape is the amount of surface inside the boundary of the shape. If you paint a shape, you are painting the area of the shape.

To calculate the area in this case, we need to break the shape into familiar shapes like triangles or rectangles. In the case above you have two rectangles. These are labelled A and B. Find the area of the rectangles, and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

AreaA=length×width=4×3=12cm2AreaB=length×width=2×4=8cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=20cm2

Therefore, the perimeter is 22 cm, and the area is 20 cm2.

Perimeter and area with a missing length

In the figure below, one of the lengths of the sides has been replaced by "z". The other five sides have the lengths shown in the figure. All of the angles in the shape are right angles, as labelled.

Determine the value of z. Then find the perimeter and the area for this figure. All lengths in the figure have dimensions of m.

Answer:
  1. The value of side z is m.
  2. The perimeter is m.
  3. The area is m2.
numeric
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Start by finding z. You can do this using the sides parallel to z, which are 7 m and 4 m long.

STEP: Determine the value of z
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

We need to find three things for this question: the value of the missing length z, the perimeter of the figure, and the area of the figure. We can start with z, because we need to know that value to find the perimeter.

To calculate z, we can use the other sides of the figure. This is because the angles are all right angles: that makes the opposite sides parallel to each other.

The side labelled z is one of two smaller sides which have the same length together as the opposite side. That opposite side has a length of 7. So we can write this equation to find z:

z+4=7z=3

The length of z is 3 m.

STEP: Find the perimeter of the figure
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 5 points left]

The perimeter is the total distance around the boundary of a two-dimensional figure. It is the distance you would walk around the shape. In the diagram above, the perimeter is the red and blue paths around the shape. To find the perimeter, we add together the lengths of all six sides of the shape.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around a shape=9+7+5+4+4+3=32

The perimeter of the shape is 32 m.

STEP: Break the shape into two rectangles to find the area
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

The area of an object is the amount of surface taken up inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape. If you tried to paint the shape, you would be painting the area of the shape. (The diagram below shows the area of the figure painted in two shades of gray.)

To calculate the area of the figure in this question we need to break the figure into shapes we can work with. For this shape, we can use two rectangles. The picture below shows these two rectangles, which are labelled A and B. We can calculate the area of rectangles A and B and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

The formula for the area of any rectangle is A=length×width. So:

AreaA=length×width=9×3=27m2AreaB=length×width=5×4=20m2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=47m2

The correct answers are:

  1. The length of side z=3m.
  2. The perimeter is 32m.
  3. The area is 47m2.

Circles: area and units

A circle has a radius of 9 cm. What is its area in mm2?

INSTRUCTION: Use π=3,14 in your calculation, and round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: The area is mm2.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by finding the radius of the circle in mm. Then calculate the area in mm2.

STEP: Convert the radius to mm
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

In this question, we need to find the area of the circle in mm2, but we have the radius in cm. One way to solve this is to start by converting the radius to mm, and then use this value to find the area in mm2.

We know that 1 cm=10 mm, so we need to multiply the radius in cm by 10. We need to multiply, because 1 cm is larger than 1 mm, so we need more mm than we have cm.

r=9 cm=9⋅10 mm=90 mm
STEP: Calculate the area in mm2
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

A=πr2

Since we know that the radius is 90 mm, we can calculate the area

A=πr2=(3,14)(90)2=25 434 mm2

The correct answer for the new area of the circle is

A=25 434 mm2

Consistent units in rectangles

Consider rectangle PQRS.

  1. Calculate the area of PQRS in cm2.

    Answer: Area = cm2
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    You need to make sure that all of the units are in cm before you do any calculations. Remember:

    • 1 cm=10 mm
    • 1 m=100 cm
    • 1 km=1 000 m
    STEP: Convert all of the units to centimetres
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    When calculating area, all of the measurements need to be consistent.

    TIP: Consistent measurements mean that all of the units are the same. For example, all of the measurements can be in cm, or all in mm. They cannot be a mixture of cm and mm.

    In this question, the length was given as 50 mm, and the breadth as 3 cm. The question asks us to calculate the area in cm2, so we must convert the length into cm.

    • 1 cm=10 mm
    • 1 m=100 cm
    • 1 km=1 000 m

    To get from mm to cm we divide 50 mm by 10:

    50÷10=5

    Therefore the length is 5 cm.

    STEP: Calculate the area in square centimetres
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    Now that all of the units are the same, we can calculate the area using the rectangle area formula:

    A=length×breadth=5×3=15 cm2
    Submit your answer as:

    • 1 km=1 000 m

    The length was given as 50 mm, and the breadth as 3 cm. This time, we need to calculate the area in mm2, so we must convert the breadth into mm.

  3. In Question 1 and 2 you calculated the same area in two different units. Use your answers to Question 1 and 2, or any other method, to answer the following question:

    How many mm2 are there in 1 cm2?
    Answer: 1 cm2 = mm2
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Draw a centimetre square and then divide it up into millimetre squares. You can also look at the relationship between the areas that you calculated in Question 1 and Question 2.

    STEP: Draw a centimetre square and divide it up into millimetre squares
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    In Question 1 and Question 2, we calculated the area of the same rectangle in different units. So, 15 cm2=1 500 mm2.

    This means that 1 cm2 = 100 mm2. This might surprise you, because 1 cm=10 mm. You might have expected units of area to convert in the same way. But, that is not the case!

    We can understand this by looking at a centimetre square, which shows 1 cm2 (not drawn to scale).

    We know that each cm contains 10 mm:

    We can now divide the square up into millimetre squares (mm2):

    There are 10 rows, each containing 10 small squares, so there are 10×10=100 millimetre squares in one centimetre square! This means that 1 cm2=100 mm2.

    We can also see this algebraically:

    1 cm2=1 cm×1 cm=(10 mm)×(10 mm)=100 mm2

    In the same way

    1 m2=1 m×1 m=(100 cm)×(100 cm)=10 000 cm2
    TIP: Area is measured in square units. So, to convert units of area, we multiply or divide by the squared number that we would used for linear conversions. For example, to convert from cm to mm we multiply by 10. To convert from cm2 to mm2 we multiply by 102=100.

Area involving circles

The diagram below shows two circles. The bigger orange circle has a radius of 3,15 km, and the white circle has a radius of 2,41 km. Calculate the shaded area only.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer:

The shaded area is km2.

one-of
type(numeric.noerror)
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Calculate the area of each of the two circles. Then subtract one value from the other.

STEP: Calculate the area of the orange region
[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

We have two circles here. The following figure shows the larger orange circle and the smaller white circle separated from each other.

To find the shaded area for this question, we need to calculate the area for both circles and then subtract. We can calculate their individual areas with the formula:

Acircle=πr2

For the orange circle, we find the larger area:

Aorange=πr2=π(3,15)2=π(9,9225)=31,17245... km2

For the white circle, we find the smaller area:

Awhite=πr2=π(2,41)2=π(5,8081)=18,24668... km2

Then to find the area of the orange region in the original picture, we need to subtract the area of the white circle from the area of the orange circle:

Aorange only=Aorange−Awhite=(31,17245...)−(18,24668...)=12,92576...=12,93 km2
NOTE: Remember to round your answer to two decimal places.

Therefore, the area of the orange region is 12,93 km2.

Which variable is the radius in this formula?

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to calculate the area of the circle. The area of an object is the surface that we can cover or paint.

Let's start with the formula for the area of a circle:

A=πr2

In this formula, the variable r stands for the radius of the circle. The question gives us the value of r. We need to substitute this into the formula to find the area of the circle.

Areas involving shapes

The following diagram shows a circle and an isosceles triangle drawn within the circle. The vertices of the triangle lie on the circumference of the circle. There is a dot at the center of the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded.

Given that the radius of the circle is 6,25 mm, calculate the shaded area.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to 2 decimal places.
Answer:

The shaded area ≈ mm2.

one-of
type(numeric.noerror)
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Calculate the areas of the circle and the triangle separately and then substract the area of the triangle from the circle of the circle. Use the fact that the triangle is isosceles to find its height.

STEP: Determine the strategy
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

We are given a circle and an isosceles triangle. The triangle is drawn within the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded. We need to calculate the area that has been shaded. To do that, we will calculate the areas of the two shapes separately and then subtract the area of the triangle from the area of the circle.

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

The area of the circle (Acircle) is:

Acircle=πr2=π(6,25)2=π(39,0625)=122,71846... mm2
STEP: Calculate the area of the triangle
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

The calculation of the area of a triangle is a bit tricky. But we can use what we know about circles to find the information we need to find the triangle's area. We need to the base and the height of the triangle to calculate it's area. (Remember that the base and the height must be perpendicular.) Each vertex of the triangle is on the circumference of the circle. That means we can find the base and the height of the triangle from the radius of the circle.

We know that the radius of the circle is 6,25 mm. The red dot is the centre of the circle, so any distance from that dot to the circle's circumference is 6,25 mm. So we can label the diagram with the information as follows:

The height of the triangle is the same as the circle's radius. And the base of the triangle is actually one radius plus another radius. These lengths are perpendicular to each other, so we can substitute this information into the formula for the area of a triangle.

ATriangle=12bh=12(6,25+6,25)×(6,25)=12(12,5)×(6,25)=39,0625 mm2
STEP: Calculate the shaded area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

To find the shaded area, we need subtract the area of the triangle from that of the circle:

Ashaded=Acircle−ATriangle=(122,71846...)−(39,0625)=83,65596...Round to twodecimal places→≈83,66mm2

The shaded area ≈83,66mm2.

Perimeter and area

Study the figure below and calculate the perimeter and the area of this figure by using the given lengths in mm.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = mm
  2. Area = mm2
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

For the perimeter, you need to find the sum (the total) of the distance around the edges of the shape. For the area, you will need to use what you know about the area of rectangles.

STEP: Find the perimeter
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The perimeter of an object is the distance around the outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. For example, the perimeter of a soccer field is the white line around the entire field. The diagram below shows the perimeter coloured red and blue.

To find the perimeter, we need to add up all six sides of the shape. We can start at any corner we want and go around until we get back where we started. We will start at the corner labelled below.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around=6+8+2+3+4+5Perimeter=28mm
NOTE: You do not have to start at the same corner: you can start at any corner and you will get the same total distance. This is because the distance around the shape is the same no matter where you start.
STEP: Break the shape into rectangles to find the area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The area of a shape is the amount of surface inside the boundary of the shape. If you paint a shape, you are painting the area of the shape.

To calculate the area in this case, we need to break the shape into familar shapes like triangles or rectangles. In the case above you have two rectangles. The rectangles are labelled A and B. Find the area of each rectangle and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

AreaA=length×width=6×5=30cm2AreaB=length×width=2×3=6cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=36mm2

Therefore, the perimeter is 28 mm, and the area is 36 mm2.

For the perimeter, you need to find the sum (the total) of the distance around the edges of the shape. For the area, you will need to use what you know about the area of rectangles.

STEP: Find the perimeter
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The perimeter of an object is the distance around the outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. For example, the perimeter of a soccer field is the white line around the entire field. The diagram below shows the perimeter coloured red and blue.

To find the perimeter, we need to add up all six sides of the shape. We can start at any corner we want and go around until we get back where we started. We will start at the corner labelled below.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around=7+9+2+3+5+6Perimeter=32cm
NOTE: You do not have to start at the same corner: you can start at any corner and you will get the same total distance. This is because the distance around the shape is the same no matter where you start.
STEP: Break the shape into two rectangles to find the area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The area of a shape is the amount of surface inside the boundary of the shape. If you paint a shape, you are painting the area of the shape.

To calculate the area in this case, we need to break the shape into familiar shapes like triangles or rectangles. In the case above you have two rectangles. These are labelled A and B. Find the area of the rectangles, and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

AreaA=length×width=7×6=42cm2AreaB=length×width=2×3=6cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=48cm2

Therefore, the perimeter is 32 cm, and the area is 48 cm2.

Perimeter and area with a missing length

In the figure below, one of the lengths of the sides has been replaced by "z". The other five sides have the lengths shown in the figure. All of the angles in the shape are right angles, as labelled.

Determine the value of z. Then find the perimeter and the area for this figure. All lengths in the figure have dimensions of cm.

Answer:
  1. The value of side z is cm.
  2. The perimeter is cm.
  3. The area is cm2.
numeric
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Start by finding z. You can do this using the sides parallel to z, which are 7 cm and 4 cm long.

STEP: Determine the value of z
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

We need to find three things for this question: the value of the missing length z, the perimeter of the figure, and the area of the figure. We can start with z, because we need to know that value to find the perimeter.

To calculate z, we can use the other sides of the figure. This is because the angles are all right angles: that makes the opposite sides parallel to each other.

The side labelled z is one of two smaller sides which have the same length together as the opposite side. That opposite side has a length of 7. So we can write this equation to find z:

z+4=7z=3

The length of z is 3 cm.

STEP: Find the perimeter of the figure
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 5 points left]

The perimeter is the total distance around the boundary of a two-dimensional figure. It is the distance you would walk around the shape. In the diagram above, the perimeter is the red and blue paths around the shape. To find the perimeter, we add together the lengths of all six sides of the shape.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around a shape=7+6+4+3+3+3=26

The perimeter of the shape is 26 cm.

STEP: Break the shape into two rectangles to find the area
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

The area of an object is the amount of surface taken up inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape. If you tried to paint the shape, you would be painting the area of the shape. (The diagram below shows the area of the figure painted in two shades of gray.)

To calculate the area of the figure in this question we need to break the figure into shapes we can work with. For this shape, we can use two rectangles. The picture below shows these two rectangles, which are labelled A and B. We can calculate the area of rectangles A and B and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

The formula for the area of any rectangle is A=length×width. So:

AreaA=length×width=7×3=21cm2AreaB=length×width=4×3=12cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=33cm2

The correct answers are:

  1. The length of side z=3cm.
  2. The perimeter is 26cm.
  3. The area is 33cm2.

[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Area is the surface of a shape or object that you can cover or paint. The pictures below show the shapes in the question "painted" in a colour; the painted place is the area of the shape.

You need to memorise each of the area formulae!!

  • Triangle: A triangle looks like the picture below. The correct formula for the area of a triangle is Atriangle=bh2. The base (b) and the height (h) of a triangle are labelled in the picture below. It is very important with a triangle that the base and the height are perpendicular to each other; otherwise this area formula will not give you the correct answer.

  • Parallelogram: A parallelogram looks like the picture below. The correct formula for the area of a parallelogram is Aparallelogram=bh. It is very important that the base (b) and the height (h) are perpendicular to each other. (You may notice that this is the same as the formula for the area of a rectangle.)

Perimeter & area: rectangles & squares

Consider the diagram of a square below.

  1. Determine the perimeter of the square and select the correct unit.

    Answer:

    Perimeter =

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. To find the perimeter of a polygon, add up the lengths of all of the sides as if you are walking all the way around the edge of the shape.

    STEP: Determine the perimeter by adding the sides
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape.

    To find the perimeter of a polygon, we add up all of the sides as if we are walking around the edge of the shape. Perimeter is a distance, so it is measured in units of length (such as mm, cm, m, or km).

    We know that all of the sides of a square are the same length.

    If we start at Point J and walk around the shape, we get

    P=3+3+3+3=12 cm
    TIP:

    All of the sides of a square are the same length. If we let the side be s, then the perimeter is

    P=s+s+s+sP=4s
    Submit your answer as: and

  2. Determine the area of the square and select the correct unit.

    Answer:

    Area =

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Area is the amount of flat space taken up by a shape. Area is measured in square units. To calculate area, you must work out how many square units will fit in the space.

    STEP: Determine area by calculating the number of square centimetres taken up by the shape
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    Area is the amount of flat space taken up by a shape. Area is measured in square units (such as mm2, cm2, m2, or km2).

    To calculate the area of the square, we must work out how many square centimetres (cm2) will fit in the space.

    We can count the squares - there are 9 square centimetres inside the square. We can also see that there are 3 columns each with 3 squares. So, there are 3×3=9 square centimetres.

    We can also calculate the area of the square using the formula.

    Area of the square:

    A=s2=32=9 cm2
    Submit your answer as: and

Circles: area and units

A circle has a radius of 2 m. What is its area in cm2?

INSTRUCTION: Use π=3,14 in your calculation, and round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: The area is cm2.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by finding the radius of the circle in cm. Then calculate the area in cm2.

STEP: Convert the radius to cm
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

In this question, we need to find the area of the circle in cm2, but we have the radius in m. One way to solve this is to start by converting the radius to cm, and then use this value to find the area in cm2.

We know that 1 m=100 cm, so we need to multiply the radius in m by 100. We need to multiply, because 1 m is larger than 1 cm, so we need more cm than we have m.

r=2 m=2⋅100 cm=200 cm
STEP: Calculate the area in cm2
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we need to calculate the area of the circle in cm2. The formula for the area of a circle is

A=πr2

Since we know that the radius is 200 cm, we can calculate the area

A=πr2=(3,14)(200)2=125 600 cm2

The correct answer for the new area of the circle is

A=125 600 cm2
Submit your answer as:

We know that 1 m=100 cm, so we need to multiply the radius in m by 100. We need to multiply, because 1 m is larger than 1 cm, so we need more cm than we have m.

r=9 m=9⋅100 cm=900 cm
STEP: Calculate the area in cm2
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we need to calculate the area of the circle in cm2. The formula for the area of a circle is

A=πr2

Since we know that the radius is 900 cm, we can calculate the area

A=πr2=(3,14)(900)2=2 543 400 cm2

The correct answer for the new area of the circle is

A=2 543 400 cm2

Answer: The area is cm2.

type(numeric.abserror(0.01))

Start by finding the radius of the circle in cm. Then calculate the area in cm2.

STEP: Convert the radius to cm
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

In this question, we need to find the area of the circle in cm2, but we have the radius in mm. One way to solve this is to start by converting the radius to cm, and then use this value to find the area in cm2.

We know that 1 cm=10 mm, so we need to divide the radius in mm by 10. We need to divide, because 1 mm is smaller than 1 cm, so we need fewer cm than we have mm.

r=6 mm=610 cm=0,6 cm
STEP: Calculate the area in cm2
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we need to calculate the area of the circle in cm2. The formula for the area of a circle is

A=πr2

A=πr2=(3,14)(0,6)2=1,1304≈1,13 cm2

The correct answer for the new area of the circle is

Consistent units in rectangles

Consider rectangle WXYZ.

  1. Calculate the area of WXYZ in cm2.

    Answer: Area = cm2
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    You need to make sure that all of the units are in cm before you do any calculations. Remember:

    • 1 cm=10 mm
    • 1 m=100 cm
    • 1 km=1 000 m
    STEP: Convert all of the units to centimetres
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    When calculating area, all of the measurements need to be consistent.

    TIP: Consistent measurements mean that all of the units are the same. For example, all of the measurements can be in cm, or all in mm. They cannot be a mixture of cm and mm.

    In this question, the length was given as 13 cm, and the breadth as 60 mm. The question asks us to calculate the area in cm2, so we must convert the breadth into cm.

    • 1 cm=10 mm
    • 1 m=100 cm
    • 1 km=1 000 m

    To get from mm to cm we divide 60 mm by 10:

    60÷10=6

    Therefore the breadth is 6 cm.

    STEP: Calculate the area in square centimetres
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    Now that all of the units are the same, we can calculate the area using the rectangle area formula:

    A=length×breadth=13×6=78 cm2
    Submit your answer as:

    • 1 km=1 000 m
    STEP: Convert all of the units to millimetres

    The length was given as 13 cm, and the breadth as 60 mm. This time, we need to calculate the area in mm2, so we must convert the length into mm.

    • 1 cm=10 mm
    • 1 m=100 cm
    • 1 km=1 000 m

  3. In Question 1 and 2 you calculated the same area in two different units. Use your answers to Question 1 and 2, or any other method, to answer the following question:

    How many mm2 are there in 1 cm2?
    Answer: 1 cm2 = mm2
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Draw a centimetre square and then divide it up into millimetre squares. You can also look at the relationship between the areas that you calculated in Question 1 and Question 2.

    STEP: Draw a centimetre square and divide it up into millimetre squares
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    In Question 1 and Question 2, we calculated the area of the same rectangle in different units. So, 78 cm2=7 800 mm2.

    This means that 1 cm2 = 100 mm2. This might surprise you, because 1 cm=10 mm. You might have expected units of area to convert in the same way. But, that is not the case!

    We can understand this by looking at a centimetre square, which shows 1 cm2 (not drawn to scale).

    We know that each cm contains 10 mm:

    We can now divide the square up into millimetre squares (mm2):

    There are 10 rows, each containing 10 small squares, so there are 10×10=100 millimetre squares in one centimetre square! This means that 1 cm2=100 mm2.

    We can also see this algebraically:

    1 cm2=1 cm×1 cm=(10 mm)×(10 mm)=100 mm2

    In the same way

    1 m2=1 m×1 m=(100 cm)×(100 cm)=10 000 cm2
    TIP: Area is measured in square units. So, to convert units of area, we multiply or divide by the squared number that we would used for linear conversions. For example, to convert from cm to mm we multiply by 10. To convert from cm2 to mm2 we multiply by 102=100.
    Submit your answer as:

Area involving circles

The diagram below shows two circles. The bigger yellow circle has a radius of 5,43 mm, and the white circle has a radius of 2,91 mm. Calculate the shaded area only.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer:

The shaded area is mm2.

one-of
type(numeric.noerror)
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Calculate the area of each of the two circles. Then subtract one value from the other.

STEP: Calculate the area of the yellow region
[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

We have two circles here. The following figure shows the larger yellow circle and the smaller white circle separated from each other.

To find the shaded area for this question, we need to calculate the area for both circles and then subtract. We can calculate their individual areas with the formula:

Acircle=πr2

For the yellow circle, we find the larger area:

Ayellow=πr2=π(5,43)2=π(29,4849)=92,62954... mm2

For the white circle, we find the smaller area:

Awhite=πr2=π(2,91)2=π(8,4681)=26,60332... mm2

Then to find the area of the yellow region in the original picture, we need to subtract the area of the white circle from the area of the yellow circle:

Ayellow only=Ayellow−Awhite=(92,62954...)−(26,60332...)=66,02622...=66,03 mm2
NOTE: Remember to round your answer to two decimal places.

Therefore, the area of the yellow region is 66,03 mm2.

Area of a circle

We need to calculate the area of the circle. The area of an object is the surface that we can cover or paint.

Let's start with the formula for the area of a circle:

A=πr2

In this formula, the variable r stands for the radius of the circle. The question gives us the value of r. We need to substitute this into the formula to find the area of the circle.

A=πr2=(3,14)(9)2=(3,14)(81)=254,34 km2

So the area is 254,34 km2.

Working backwards from area: squares and rectangles

The area of the square drawn below is 25 cm2.

Determine the value of y and select the correct unit.

Answer:

y=

numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Area is the amount of flat space taken up by a shape. Use the formula for the area of a square and the given information to create an equation.

STEP: Use the area formula for a square to make an equation
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

The formula for area of a square is: A=s2

We know the area of the square is 25 cm2.

25=y2
The equation y2=25 has two solutions: 5 or −5. But, y is always positive because it is a length. So, we throw away the negative solution.
y=√25y=5 cm
NOTE: We must use units of length for the length of the side (such as mm, cm, m, or km).

Aorange=πr2=π(5,46)2=π(29,8116)=93,65590... m2

For the white circle, we find the smaller area:

Awhite=πr2=π(2,35)2=π(5,5225)=17,34944... m2

Then to find the area of the orange region in the original picture, we need subtract the area of the white circle from the area of the orange circle:

Aorange only=Aorange−Awhite=(93,65590...)−(17,34944...)=76,30645...=76,31 m2
NOTE: Remember to round your answer to two decimal places.

Therefore, the area of the orange region is 76,31 m2.

Areas involving shapes

The following diagram shows a circle and an isosceles triangle drawn within the circle. The vertices of the triangle lie on the circumference of the circle. There is a dot at the center of the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded.

Given that the radius of the circle is 6,04 cm, calculate the shaded area.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to 2 decimal places.
Answer:

The shaded area ≈ cm2.

one-of
type(numeric.noerror)
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Calculate the areas of the circle and the triangle separately and then substract the area of the triangle from the circle of the circle. Use the fact that the triangle is isosceles to find its height.

STEP: Determine the strategy
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

We are given a circle and an isosceles triangle. The triangle is drawn within the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded. We need to calculate the area that has been shaded. To do that, we will calculate the areas of the two shapes separately and then subtract the area of the triangle from the area of the circle.

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

The area of the circle (Acircle) is:

Acircle=πr2=π(6,04)2=π(36,4816)=114,61032... cm2
STEP: Calculate the area of the triangle
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

The calculation of the area of a triangle is a bit tricky. But we can use what we know about circles to find the information we need to find the triangle's area. We need to the base and the height of the triangle to calculate it's area. (Remember that the base and the height must be perpendicular.) Each vertex of the triangle is on the circumference of the circle. That means we can find the base and the height of the triangle from the radius of the circle.

We know that the radius of the circle is 6,04 cm. The red dot is the centre of the circle, so any distance from that dot to the circle's circumference is 6,04 cm. So we can label the diagram with the information as follows:

The height of the triangle is the same as the circle's radius. And the base of the triangle is actually one radius plus another radius. These lengths are perpendicular to each other, so we can substitute this information into the formula for the area of a triangle.

ATriangle=12bh=12(6,04+6,04)×(6,04)=12(12,08)×(6,04)=36,4816 cm2
STEP: Calculate the shaded area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

To find the shaded area, we need subtract the area of the triangle from that of the circle:

Ashaded=Acircle−ATriangle=(114,61032...)−(36,4816)=78,12872...Round to twodecimal places→≈78,13cm2

The shaded area ≈78,13cm2.

Perimeter and area

Study the figure below and calculate the perimeter and the area of this figure by using the given lengths in m.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = m
  2. Area = m2
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

For the perimeter, you need to find the sum (the total) of the distance around the edges of the shape. For the area, you will need to use what you know about the area of rectangles.

STEP: Find the perimeter
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The perimeter of an object is the distance around the outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. For example, the perimeter of a soccer field is the white line around the entire field. The diagram below shows the perimeter coloured red and blue.

To find the perimeter, we need to add up all six sides of the shape. We can start at any corner we want and go around until we get back where we started. We will start at the corner labelled below.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around=6+9+2+2+4+7Perimeter=30m
NOTE: You do not have to start at the same corner: you can start at any corner and you will get the same total distance. This is because the distance around the shape is the same no matter where you start.
STEP: Break the shape into rectangles to find the area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The area of a shape is the amount of surface inside the boundary of the shape. If you paint a shape, you are painting the area of the shape.

To calculate the area in this case, we need to break the shape into familar shapes like triangles or rectangles. In the case above you have two rectangles. The rectangles are labelled A and B. Find the area of each rectangle and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

AreaA=length×width=6×7=42cm2AreaB=length×width=2×2=4cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=46m2

Therefore, the perimeter is 30 m, and the area is 46 m2.

Missing lengths

Study the figure OPQRS below. The figure is drawn to scale.

Side ¯OP=18m , ¯PQ= Not given , ¯QR=24m , ¯RS=30m , ¯SO=10,42m.

Calculate the perimeter and the area of the figure. Round your answer to two decimal places.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = m
  2. Area = m2
numeric
numeric
STEP: <no title>
[−5 points ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

¯PQ=¯OS (Opposite sides of a rectangle are equal)

The perimeter = 92,84 m

The area = 403,56m2

Perimeter is the border or outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure - the "distance " you would walk around the shape. In this specific case above, you follow the red lines ¯OP and ¯PQ, then the blue lines ¯QRand ¯RS, then the final red line ¯SO back to the start. Remember you are only adding distances in one dimension so the unit for your answer will be m only.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around=18+10,42+24+30+10,42=18+10,42+24+30+10,42Perimeter=92,84m

Area is the amount of space inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape - the " space " inside the perimeter. To calculate the area try and divide the compound shape into simpler shapes with a familiar formula. In the case above you have areaA a rectangle and areaB a triangle. Remember you are multiplying m by m which means your unit for your answer shoud be m2.

AreaA=length×width=18×10,42=187,56m2AreaB=12base×height=12(18×24)=216m2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=403,56m2

Therefore, the perimeter = 92.84m and the area = 403.56m2.

STEP: Determine the value of z
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

We need to find three things for this question: the value of the missing length z, the perimeter of the figure, and the area of the figure. We can start with z, because we need to know that value to find the perimeter.

To calculate z, we can use the other sides of the figure. This is because the angles are all right angles: that makes the opposite sides parallel to each other.

The side labelled z is one of two smaller sides which have the same length together as the opposite side. That opposite side has a length of 10. So we can write this equation to find z:

z+6=10z=4

The length of z is 4 cm.

STEP: Find the perimeter of the figure
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 5 points left]

The perimeter is the total distance around the boundary of a two-dimensional figure. It is the distance you would walk around the shape. In the diagram above, the perimeter is the red and blue paths around the shape. To find the perimeter, we add together the lengths of all six sides of the shape.

Perimeter=Sum of the distance around a shape=10+10+3+4+7+6=40

The perimeter of the shape is 40 cm.

STEP: Break the shape into two rectangles to find the area
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

The area of an object is the amount of surface taken up inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape. If you tried to paint the shape, you would be painting the area of the shape. (The diagram below shows the area of the figure painted in two shades of gray.)

To calculate the area of the figure in this question we need to break the figure into shapes we can work with. For this shape, we can use two rectangles. The picture below shows these two rectangles, which are labelled A and B. We can calculate the area of rectangles A and B and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

The formula for the area of any rectangle is A=length×width. So:

AreaA=length×width=10×6=60cm2AreaB=length×width=3×4=12cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=72cm2

The correct answers are:

  1. The length of side z=4cm.
  2. The perimeter is 40cm.
  3. The area is 72cm2.
Submit your answer as: andand

Perimeter and area by squares

Find the perimeter and the area of this figure by using the grid its plotted on.
Each square represents a 1 km×1 km area.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = km
  2. Area = km2
numeric
numeric
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to break the shape into two recetangles, as shown below.

  • Perimeter is the border or outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. It is the distance you would walk around the shape.
    Perimeter = Sum of the distance around=7 sqrs across+8 sqrs down+4 sqrs across +2 sqrs up+3 sqrs across+6 sqrs up=7+8+4+2+3+6Perimeter =30 km2
  • Area is the amount of space inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape. It is the space inside the perimeter. To calculate the area, try to divide the compound shape into simpler shapes with familiar area formulae, usually squares or rectangles. In the case above, you have a yellow rectangle and a blue rectangle.
    AreaY=length×width=7×6=42 km2AreaB=length×width=4×2=8 km2AreaTotal=AreaY+AreaB=50 km2

Therefore, the perimeter is 30 km and the area is 50 km2.

Perimeter and area by squares

Find the perimeter and the area of this figure by using the grid its plotted on.
Each square represents a 1 mm×1 mm area.

  1. Perimeter = mm
  2. Area = mm2

numeric

    Perimeter = Sum of the distance around=1 sqrs across+9 sqrs down+3 sqrs across +1 sqrs up+2 sqrs across+8 sqrs up=1+9+3+1+2+8Perimeter =24 mm2
  • Area is the amount of space inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape. It is the space inside the perimeter.   • Area is the amount of space inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape. It is the space inside the perimeter. 4. Practical applications

Choose appropriate units

For each of the following scenarios, choose the most appropriate unit of measurement.

  1. The following diagram shows a wall that is being painted.

    What is the most appropriate unit for measuring the surface of the wall?

    Answer:

    The most appropriate unit is:

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Distance or length is measured using units (such as mm, cm, m, or km).

    Area is measured using unit squares (such as mm2, cm2, m2, or even km2).

    STEP: How do we measure flat space?
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    We measure two-dimensional space by working out how many unit squares will fit into the space. Examples of units of measurement for area are mm2, cm2, m2, or even km2.

    A square millimetre (mm2) is a tiny square with sides each one millimetre long. It is about the size of a flattened breadcrumb.

    A square centimetre (cm2) is the size of a square with sides each one centimetre long. It is about the size of your thumbnail.

    A square metre (m2) is the size of a square with sides each one metre long. It is about the space on the floor that you need to sit cross-legged.

    A square kilometre (km2) is the space inside a square with sides each one kilometre. It is a very big unit for measuring area. You can fit about ten soccer fields into one square kilometre!

    STEP: About how much surface is there on a wall?
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    Walls are usually a few metres long and around two metres high.

    Square centimetres could be used, but they would be a bit small to measure a wall. The most appropriate unit from this list is m2.

    NOTE: When we are measuring length we use m. But we are not measuring length here, we are measuring area. So we have to use square units.
    Submit your answer as:

  2. What is the most appropriate unit for measuring the length of your arm?

    Answer:

    The most appropriate unit is:

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Distance or length is measured using units (such as mm, cm, m, or km).

    Area is measured using unit squares (such as mm2, cm2, m2, or even km2).

    STEP: How do we measure length?
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Distance or length is measured using units (such as mm, cm, m, or km).

    Millimetres (mm) and centimetres (cm) are appropriate for measuring short lengths. They are on your ruler:

    Metres (m) are bigger - about the length of one big step or three rulers placed end to end. There are 100 centimetres in one metre.

    Kilometres (km) are good for measuring longer distances. It takes about 20 minutes to walk one kilometre (if you are walking at a relaxed speed). There are 1 000 metres in one kilometre.

    STEP: How long is your arm?
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    Your arm will be between half a metre and one metre in length. We could use metres for measuring arm length, but then we would need to use decimals to measure accurately. Another good unit is centimetres, because then we can get an accurate measurement without using decimals.

    The average length of a 13-year-old's arm is 73 cm. (Try measuring yours!) So, the most appropriate unit from the list is cm.

    NOTE: When we measure an arm we are measuring length. So we cannot use square units like cm2 to measure it. Square units are for measuring area.
    Submit your answer as:

  2. The following diagram shows the distribution of land in South Africa by province. The Northern Cape is the biggest province with 29,7% of the land area. Gauteng is the smallest, with 1,4% of the land area.
